awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: A Robotic Gripper with a Tunable Stiffness for Grasping Versatile Objects
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project offers a robotic prototype to perform tasks such as sorting, picking, and placing objects that are pervasive in e-commence, warehouse, agriculture automation, and manufacturing. If this robotic gripper is commercialized, it will help small and medium businesses rapidly adjust existing or establish new automation lines in response to market needs, reducing costs and enhancing their competitiveness in the global market. Moreover, the developed technology in the project may be also beneficial to other applications such as high performance prosthetic hands with a variable stiffness for enhanced load-carrying capacity. In the proposed broadening participation plan, Professor Su will work closely with coordinators of the Metro Early College High School (MECHS) in central Columbus to identify and recruit talented (especially minority and underrepresented) MECHS students to complete both a Summer Internship and Capstone Research Internship in the research lab. 

The proposed project aims to develop a scale-up prototype of a variable stiffness-compliant robotic gripper for versatile tasks in unstructured environments. Current gripper technologies offer either a high payload or a high adaptability, and this may limit their applications. The proposed variable stiffness gripper can be switched between a soft mode to a rigid mode on demand based on a recently developed layer jamming technology. The proposed applied research plan fills several knowledge gaps and overcomes key technical obstacles for commercialization. The applied research tasks are: (1) development of a scaling law to tailor design parameters for a specific performance metric; (2) design optimization of the compliant backbone to further improve the stiffness ratio and enhance robustness of the vacuum bag; (3) development of a scale-up prototype of the robotic gripper and demonstration with an industrial robotic manipulator. The technology combines the merits of rigid-body and soft grippers and may have both a high shape adaptability and a high payload capacity.  This gripper technology offers key technical differentiators: significantly increased payload capacity and reduced power consumption in grasping.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
To goal of this PFI-TT project is to develop a scale-up prototype of variable stiffness compliant robotic gripper (VSCRG) for versatile tasks in unstructured environments. During the project duration period, we have successfully developed multiple prototypes of variable stiffness robotic gripper and tested them in various application scenarios. We have also explored the opportunities for commercializing this gripper.

Intellectual merits: The variable stiffness gripper is not only highly adaptable just like most soft grippers, but more importantly capable of grasping heavy (about 6-10kg) objects comparable to its rigid-body counterparts. The gripper design has been optimized for simplified manufacturing. Several manufacturing methods including customized 3d printing, soft material molding and soft material printing have been explored to fabricate the gripper. A pneumatic controller for the gripper to control the three fingers of the gripper has also been developed. The entire gripping system has been tested on an industrial robotic arm for pick and place tasks. The results showed that the gripper met the basic requirements with room to improve. The variable stiffness gripper technology has been extended to designs with multi segments for higher adaptability and improved payload capacity. A high performance prosthetic hand with five fingers with variable stiffness was developed. The test results show that the variable stiffness technology enhances the payload capacity while enjoying the benefits of the high adaptability feature of soft material.

Broader Impacts: PI and his team have participated I-Corps@Ohio and NSF I-Corps cohort programs which allow us explore the potential of the gripper technology for commercial applications. In the I-Corps@Ohio program, the team started from manufacturing industries such as automotive and expanded into other industries such as agricultural automation, commercial dishwashing. We concluded that the gripper technology may be suitable for agricultural automation such as fruit harvesting and commercial dishwashing. In the NSF I-Corps program, we took the opportunity and explored the commercial dishwashing application in more depth. Through the extensive interviews, we have found that the gripper technology may be the best fit for commercial dishwashing as alternative gripper solution can be used.

In addition to the commercialization exploration, we have also conducted significant outreach activities. In particular, PI sponsored at least two senior capstone projects for students from Metro Early College High School (MECHS). Also PI hosted 2-3 summer interns in PI’s lab. In these projects, students learned the basic skills of programming robotic arm for pick and place tasks. They also work with undergraduate and graduate students on this project. These research activities help young generations gain the first- hand experience of STEM disciplines and motivate them pursue degree and career in STEM.

 


Last Modified: 11/27/2023
Modified by: Hai-Jun Su
